item.description: An original song dedicated to HKers

item.description: Also known as ‘The Anthem’

item.title: Sing Hallelujah to the Lord
item.description: A Christian hymn that was popularised in the 2019 protests.

item.title: 二零一九 by LMF
item.description: New 2019 song by LMF

item.title: 試問誰還未發聲
item.description: Cantonese version of ‘Do you hear the people sing’ from the musical Les Miserables

item.title: Hong Kong, is officially on fire.
item.description: Fury. I could see it in the eyes of the people around me, our minds reeling from the bombshell that our government had just dropped on us this afternoon.

item.title: March of the Indomitables/不屈進行曲
item.description: Another piece by dgx studio

item.title: An open later to Foreigners residing in Hong Kong
item.description: It does not matter if you are Gweilo, Filipino, Nepali or if you belong to any other people, this land is our land and our land is your land.

item.title: If you've come to congratulate us, don't. Our struggle is far from over
item.description: I’ve been getting messages from expats and friends from overseas, congratulating the people of HK for a job well done. It’s not a job well done.

item.title: 肥媽有話兒
item.description: A viral video with edited lyrics, music based on Sia’s Chandelier

item.title: We Are What We Are Made Of
item.description: Beginning from every day tears are shed: their tails are puffs of smoke.

item.title: 香港之歌 Medley
item.description: A medley for Hong Kong people

item.title: 逃
item.description: A Song by Arho Sunny

item.title: About
item.description: About Liberty for Hong Kong Liberty for Hong Kong, or L4HK is a non-profit and collaborative project to crowdsource and document Hong Kong’s journey to achieving meaningful freedom, democracy, and autonomy. This project was first created in the wake of the 2019 Anti-Extradition Bill protests. Check us out on GitHub. L4HK is not supported or funded by any organisation. Introduction The 2019 protests against the controversial extradition bill in Hong Kong unearthed a network of underlying factors and forces which threaten to erode the civil liberties of its citizens.

item.title: Art
item.description: Art A gallery showcasing the artworks of the 2019 protests. div.gallery { display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; } div.gallery a { flex-grow: 1; object-fit: cover; margin: 2px; display: flex; } div.gallery a img { height: 200px; object-fit: cover; flex-grow: 1; }

item.title: Contribute
item.description: Contribute This page is currently under active development, and welcome all kinds of contribution where possible. For more information, please check out our GitHub repository. How to contribute using GitHub repository Contributing articles Pre-requisites: you’ll need a GitHub account. If you’re unfamiliar with Markdown, it will also be helpful to use a Markdown editor such as Typora (for Windows users), Notepad++, or ghostwriter. Create a Markdown post (files with the extension .

item.title: Declaration of Hong Kong Protestors / 香港人抗爭宣言
item.description: Dear Hongkongers, We are protesters from the civic society. If there’s a choice, we wish we didn’t have to protest against tyranny with our own bodies, and didn’t have to occupy the Hong Kong Legislative Council as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the Government. But the Government has put aside all principles and procedures, ignored the demands of Hong Kong People, and repeated their lame arguments and lied over and over again.

item.title: Documentary
item.description: Please see partial documentary-gallery.html To update content, go to data > documentary.yml The id parameter overrides any content shown here - to change this, add {{ .Content }}

item.title: Slogans
item.description: Note: The primary source material is taken from Mary Hui’s QZ article.1 Please support the original author by visiting the original site. Take Back Hong Kong, the Revolution of Our Time //光復香港，時代革命 The clarion call of the current wave of ongoing protests—also often translated as “liberate” or “reclaim”—this slogan traces its roots back to the election campaign of activist Edward Leung, currently serving a six-year prison sentence for rioting and assaulting a police officer during the so-called Fishball Revolution of 2016.

item.title: Timeline - 2019 Protests
item.description: Timeline -- Jump to: 7.21 8.11 8.31 9.4 (Full Bill Withdrawal) First proposal of extradition bill February, 2019 The Fugitive Offenders and Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation (Amendment) Bill 2019 was first proposed by the government of Hong Kong on February 2019 in response to the 2018 murder of Poon Hiu-wing by her boyfriend Chan Tong-kai in Taiwan, where the two Hong Kong residents were visiting as tourists.
